definition: to open up a port for trade/to open treaty ports

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format

sentences.english: After Chongqing opened the port, "modern agitation " poured into Sichuan Basin along the course of the Changjiang River.
sentences.chinese: 重庆开埠后，“近代风潮”沿长江航线涌进四川盆地。

sentences.english: Before opening the port, HanKow was already a prosperous town.
sentences.chinese: 开埠之前，汉口已是一个繁华的商业市镇。

sentences.english: After being opened, Zhoucun's commerce started its way of modernization.
sentences.chinese: 周村开埠后，城市商业开始了近代化的历史征途。

sentences.english: Hong Kong was founded as a port for the China trade just over 150 years ago.
sentences.chinese: 香港在150多年前开埠之时是中国的通商港。

sentences.english: Shanghai accelerated its development at an unusual speed after it was open to the outside world.
sentences.chinese: 但是上海自开埠以来，以超常的速度发展。

sentences.english: Since the mid 16th century, when the Macao opened the port, Christianity was introduced into china in the third time.
sentences.chinese: 16世纪中叶澳门开埠后，基督教第三次传入中国。

sentences.english: The introduction of Western paintings to Hong Kong can be dated back to early 19th century.
sentences.chinese: 香港西画的发展，至早可追溯到十九世纪开埠初。

sentences.english: Yantai is one of China's earliest open port cities.
sentences.chinese: 烟台，中国第一批对外开埠通商的城市之一。

definition: the five treaty ports forced on Qing China by the 1842 treaty of Nanjing 南京條約|南京条约 that concluded the First Opium War, namely: Guangzhou 廣州|广州, Fuzhou 福州, Ningbo 寧波|宁波, Xiamen or Amoy 廈門|厦门 and Shanghai 上海
treaty port, forced on Qing China by the 19th century Great Powers
foreign concession, an enclave occupied by a foreign power (in China in the 19th and 20th centuries)
the final years of the Ch'ing or Qing dynasty/China at the turn of the 20th century
Treaty of Nanjing (1842) that concluded the First Opium War between Qing China and Britain
the late Qing and early Republic, i.e. China around 1911

the not-very-distant past/modern times, excluding recent decades/(in the context of Chinese history) the period from the Opium Wars until the May 4th Movement (mid-19th century to 1919)/capitalist times (pre-1949)
Weihaiwei, late Qing naval port in Weihai 威海, Shandong
